body:
We would like to use a hardware wallet to sign transactions when using Hardhat for migration. With Truffle that's easy, since we can specify a custom `provider` function in the `truffle-config.js` file. Perhaps I'm missing something, but I didn't find any information in the [docs](https://hardhat.org/config/#json-rpc-based-networks) on how to do this.

About 1-2 years ago we had issues with every ledger web3 provider library that we tried and ended up writing our own:
* repo: https://gitlab.com/jarvis-network/base/libraries/js/ledger-web3-provider
* npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@jarvis-network/ledger-web3-provider

So obviously, we would like to use our library with Hardhat ;) We're open to making changes to it if necessary in order to support Hardhat.

[Frame](https://github.com/floating/frame) was built with this use case in mind. It provides a system-wide signing interface with native support for both Ledger and Trezor devices.

All you need to do is update your deployment script to something like:

```
    // Create a Frame connection
    const ethProvider = require('eth-provider') // eth-provider is a simple EIP-1193 provider
    const frame = ethProvider('frame') // Connect to Frame

    // Use `getDeployTransaction` instead of `deploy` to return deployment data
    const Greeter = await ethers.getContractFactory('Greeter')
    const tx = await Greeter.getDeployTransaction()
   
    // Set `tx.from` to current Frame account
    tx.from = (await frame.request({ method: 'eth_requestAccounts' }))[0]
    
    // Sign and send the transaction using Frame
    await frame.request({ method: 'eth_sendTransaction', params: [tx] })
 ```
 
You can use this pattern to sign with your hardware and deploy to any network

Get Frame: https://frame.sh
Install eth-provider: `npm install eth-provider`

If you'd rather use your own provider instead of `eth-provider` just connect to one of Frame's JSON-RPC endpoints, `ws://127.0.0.1:1248`  or `http://127.0.0.1:1248`

If you have any problems feel free to open issues at either:
https://github.com/floating/frame
https://github.com/floating/eth-provider

Hope this is helpful!

I was able to get it working with ethers on a simple script.

Install the hardware wallet library if missing:
`npm install -s @ethersproject/hardware-wallets`

In the script, swap out the signer:
```
const { LedgerSigner } = require("@ethersproject/hardware-wallets");    
const ledger = await new LedgerSigner(contractFactory.signer.provider, "hid", "m/44'/60'/0'/0");                                                                                                                              
contractFactory = await contractFactory.connect(ledger)
```

run with `sudo npx hardhat run ./script` or you'll likely get an access error (on linux anyway)
Is there any update on this?

@bghughes no, not yet. The way this will probably be implemented is by using a feature that we don't have yet: the ability to wrap the provider to add extra functionality. And we don't have that on our roadmap at the moment.

For now, you'll need to use one of the mentioned workarounds.

I've actually managed to make a plugin with my own provider. I'm using KMS for signing, but you can easily repurpose it for a hardware wallet.
You can find code here: https://github.com/rumblefishdev/hardhat-kms-signer
@kowalski how would you repurpose this for a Ledger?

> @kowalski how would you repurpose this for a Ledger?

Basically change this line: https://github.com/rumblefishdev/hardhat-kms-signer/blob/746533e79cc7e48ce31b503be79e2e153f74e125/src/provider.ts#L61 to use ledger library to ask it to generate signature of `txf.getMessageToSign()`. Than format the signature into `r`, `v` and `s` - format the ethereum libraries expect.
